com.nttdocomo.util
Class Timer

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.nttdocomo.util.Timer
All Implemented Interfaces:
TimeKeeper
public final class Timer
extends java.lang.Object
implements TimeKeeper

This is a timer class. It supports the one shot timer and interval timer. TimerListener can be registered as a listener to receive a timer event. When a timer event is generated, the timeExpired method of a listener object is called.
The time scope is in application units.
The timer secures the native resource at the start and releases it at the stop.

When an application is suspended, the timer stops. This is the same status as when the stop method is called.

See Also:
ShortTimer

Constructor Detail

Timer

public Timer()
Creates a timer object. This constructor initializes the timer as no repeating (one shot timer), set time 0ms, and no listener registration.

Method Detail

getResolution

public int getResolution()
This obtains the timer resolution. The timer resolution is the minimum interval from the occurrence of one timer event to the next occurrence. This interval varies from system to system.

Specified by:
getResolution in interface TimeKeeper
Returns:
The timer resolution in a unit of milliseconds.

start

public void start()
This starts the timer.

Specified by:
start in interface TimeKeeper
Throws:
UIException - Generated when an attempt is made to use the start method after the calling start is called by the method in an interval timer or when an attempt is made to use the start method before receiving timer notification after the one shot timer calls the start method(ILLEGAL_STATE).
UIException - Generated when a native resource could not be secured (NO_RESOURCES).

stop

public void stop()
This stops the timer. When this method is called while the timer is stopped, nothing occurs.

Specified by:
stop in interface TimeKeeper

dispose

public void dispose()
This disposes the timer. A UIException is generated when a method other than dispose is called after calling this method (ILLEGAL_STATE). Nothing occurs when the dispose method is called after calling this method.

Specified by:
dispose in interface TimeKeeper

setRepeat

public void setRepeat(boolean repeat)
This sets whether timer events are to be generated repeatedly. In default, events are set to occur only once.

Parameters:
repeat - Designates true for repeated occurrence and false for only one occurrence.
Throws:
UIException - Generated when an attempt is made to call this method after calling the start method (ILLEGAL_STATE).

setTime

public void setTime(int interval)
This sets the time interval of timer events.

Parameters:
interval - Designates the timer event intervals in a unit of milliseconds.
Throws:
UIException - Generated when an attempt is made to call this method after the start method is called (ILLEGAL_STATE).
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - Generated when the value of the argument time is negative.

setListener

public void setListener(TimerListener listener)
This sets the listener object that receives timer events.
When a timer event occurs, the timeExpired method of the designated listener object is called. Only one listener can be set. When several listeners are set, only the one set last is valid.
When the listener is set after starting the timer, only the timer events after the setting of the listener shall be notified.

Parameters:
listener - Designates the listener object
